paper_metadata.title: Building resilience against droughts: Evidence from a graduation model program in Ethiopia

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: in some arms, there was also a one-time livelihoods transfer targeting the poorest beneficiaries

component_b_assets.assets_evidence_citation: The SPIR program led to substantial increases in accumulation of livestock assets as well as increased income from livestock products

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: We measure impacts on food security, livestock holdings, women's diet diversity, women's body mass index and intimate partner violence
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: We use data from a cluster randomized control trial (RCT) that evaluated a multifaceted graduation model program within the context of Ethiopia's Productive Safety Net Programme

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: Strengthen PSNP4 Institutions and Resilience (SPIR) was a five-year project delivering bundled livelihoods, nutrition, and gender interventions to PSNP beneficiaries
evidence_citations.country_citation: We use data from a cluster randomized control trial (RCT) that evaluated a multifaceted graduation model program within the context of Ethiopia's Productive Safety Net Programme
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: The study population is formed of beneficiaries of a large-scale and long running safety net program that provides regular albeit small cash or food payments against labor intensive public works
